content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: WWII men supported the wars on all fronts and the people stood beside and behind them. They know what sacrifice meant. I beg to differ on this point. My father was a member of a Military Police Battalion from 1943 until the end of WWII. Their job was to travel around the United States, putting down anti-draft riots. He was severely injured breaking up a draft riot in South Boston, Massachusetts, in 1944 and recieved disability payments for his injuries annually until he died this year. However, there was one silver lining: While assigned to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in 1945 to put down draft riots there, he met my mother at a USO square dance and married her the week after VJ-Day. They were married 53 years before her death and had my brother and I.

content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: WWII men supported the wars on all fronts and the people stood beside and behind them. They know what sacrifice meant. I beg to differ on this point. My father was a member of a Military Police Battalion from 1943 until the end of WWII. Their job was to travel around the United States, putting down anti-draft riots. He was severely injured breaking up a draft riot in South Boston, Massachusetts, in 1944 and recieved disability payments for his injuries annually until he died this year. However, there was one silver lining: While assigned to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in 1945 to put down draft riots there, he met my mother at a USO square dance and married her the week after VJ-Day. They were married 53 years before her death and had my brother and I.

content: quote: Originally posted by klassylady25: WWII men supported the wars on all fronts and the people stood beside and behind them. They know what sacrifice meant. I beg to differ on this point. My father was a member of a Military Police Battalion from 1943 until the end of WWII. Their job was to travel around the United States, putting down anti-draft riots. He was severely injured breaking up a draft riot in South Boston, Massachusetts, in 1944 and recieved disability payments for his injuries annually until he died this year. However, there was one silver lining: While assigned to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in 1945 to put down draft riots there, he met my mother at a USO square dance and married her the week after VJ-Day. They were married 53 years before her death and had my brother and I.
